ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I improved various Spanish skills, like writing/grammar and speaking. I also learned a great deal of information about the details of the Spanish law system (and some other Spanish-speaking countries too). Through the oral presentation and final paper, you also get to learn a lot about a specific topic (e.g. gun rights, domestic violence, drug use), but you learn this information yourself.

- practice writing and researching in Spanish
- oral speaking skills, oral comprehension skills
- familiarity with legal concepts and vocabulary
Brushed up, solidified, and expanded my knowledge of Spanish
I learned how the legal system worked for Spanish speaking countries as well as a general foundation of law.

I learned to speak and write high-level, professional Spanishespecially pertaining to legal jargon. In addition, I learned a lot about continental legal systems (mostly in Spain and general Latin American countries).

I was able to enhance my communication abilities in Spanish tremendously. By concentrating narrowly on a specific domain of Spanish, within the legal field, I was able to better prepare for my aspiring career as an attorney. This class also helped me with my knowledge of Spanish culture and my own ethnicity. I discovered things about myself that I wouldn't have been able to without this class, such as my fascination with immigration law and Cuban immigration to the United States.
I developed a better understanding of Spanish vocabulary related to the law, and I gained a solid understanding of basic legal concepts as well.
general overview of legal systems and spanish legal vocabulary
I learned how to speak Spanish in the context of legal manners and I learned about the legal system in Latin America.

I improved my understanding of law in the Spanish-speaking world and how it differs among countries, and learned about different areas of law and factors that are relevant to each. My ability at speaking, writing, and comprehending Spanish also got better because of this courseespecially my writing.
I learned about the Spanish legal system and improved my writing skills.
I improved my reading, writing, speaking, and listening in Spanish. I learned about the nuances of the legal systems in Spain and Latin American countries.
I practiced spanish speaking skills, comprehension, and gained increased cultural awareness

I learned about the legal world of Spanish society and discussed multiple aspects of how laws influence societal interactions and consequences (not limited to Spain but also within the United States).

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think of the weaknesses of the course was that some of the writing assignments felt kind of pointless they were often just summaries of the information from the textbook. Besides that, I think the class had a lot of strengths. Going back to the writing assignments, they were very useful in improving my writing skills and Profesora Carreras gave individualized feedback on all of them. They also were not very time-consuming, which was nice. I also like how each class wasn't necessarily the same. It was a combination of lecturing, discussing questions, watching videos, etc.

- sometimes we spent the entire class watching videos/TV shows in English. These felt like a waste of time, unfortunately.
- I enjoyed the final paper and midterm presentation projects and the freedom we had in choosing topics
Classes were pretty straightforward and engaging, with weekly writing assignments being fairly manageable.

The syllabus/canvas assignments ended up being different from what was actually assigned which was confusing. The class was also very large and there was a noticiable divide between native speakers and non native speakers. Outside this, both the profesor and the coursework were very enjoyable and I learned a lot.

Strengths: Weekly writing assignments with ample feedback allowed me to practice writing Spanish very effectively. The lectures were always accompanies with a great deal of classroom discussion that allowed students to share their stances on different topics of the legal system. 
Weakness: 9 am class... (though better times were available but filled)

I think one major strength was the flexibility of the curriculum. Students were able to choose their own topic for the group presentation; which I found incredibly helpful in my own research in the class. The class also covered multiple facets of law in Spanish, which I appreciated. I can't think of a way it can be improved to be frank.

This course is helpful for learning to write well in Spanish; Prof. Carreras provided very helpful feedback on all written assignments to help with grammar. Because the class size was larger than most seminar language courses, I found it was more challenging to practice speaking.
The course is well-structured with a consistent, two assignments due each week. The canvas site and syllabus could be better organized to maintain accuracy with the class.

strength is that weekly written responses help with writing
weakness is that the classes are a little bit repetitive in the style, lacking engagement in simple textbook material review, doesn't help with vigorous language learning

strengths: Professor Carreras is an excellent professor and thoroughly explains each idea so that it is easy to understand. She provides real world examples and complements them with real cases

weakness: The class sometimes lacks discussion

Strengths: Received lots of feedback on written assignments, very interesting class conversations and discussion prompts, lots of opportunities to participate, readings were at the right level of difficulty and were relevant to what we talked about in class. 
Weaknesses: None.

Professor Carreras does a good job of relating the content to current events. We watched interesting videos and discussed relevant topics within the context of the law we had learned about. At times, the course goes very deep into the specifics of the law and can get a bit tedious.

This course was well-structured (readings, in-class discussions, writing assignments, and a presentation). I felt that I had the opportunity to learn from my peers from in-class discussions and the group presentation. The readings and writing assignments allowed me to explore the nuances of various legal systems. The videos helped me to learn more about class topics and improve my listening abilities. My Spanish also improved tremendously because of the detailed feedback I received on assignments. However, one weakness of this class was the size: not everyone in the class could participate in the discussions, and there were not enough seats at the discussion table so many people had to sit at chairs on the side. I think this could be easily remedied by making the class size smaller.
I did not like reading and doing activities outlined in the textbook. They were very dry and oftentimes boring.

Strengths: The professor does an excellent job at discussing the topics in a seminar-like fashion and offers students the opportunity to answer questions consistently. 
Weakness: The course could be improved with a more elaborate powerpoint presentations as the ones offered are quite bare and do not serve as very good note taking sources. Students would need to keep up with the professor's quick change in topic and tangents.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to another student. I think it's best suited for students who may just have finished L4 or haven't taken Spanish in a while, since it's not too demanding but will make sure that you learn the necessary skills to improve your Spanish. It's also not a high workload and Profesora Carreras is wonderful.
Depends. This course does not require much work outside of class. It also is not the most rewarding and it's hard to feel like you're learning a lot.
Absolutely. Mercedes is a great instructor, approachable, and her lectures are always engaging.
Yes! This is a great course that combines introductory law and Spanish. The coursework is quite easy but you still manage to learn a lot, especially if you participate in class and do the readings!

Absolutely! This course was a great introduction to the Latin American and Spanish legal systems. It is also allowed students to refine their Spanish-speaking/writing abilities while being engaged with the content. A great L5 Spanish course!
Absolutely, to any person who wants to gain more legal knowledge while simultaneously improving their Spanish skills, this is the course for them.
Yes, Prof Carreras is great, and the course is pretty engaging.
If you are looking for a chill Spanish class or general overview of the legal systems, I'd recommend it. But this is not a class that focuses on the improvement in your Spanish language skills.
Yes, it is a great course to learn and apply spanish skills in a relatively relaxed way. Professor Carreras is a great teacher and you learn a lot but it is not a stressful class.

Yes! Very interesting content, Sra. Carreras is extremely nice, workload was quite reasonable. This class also really improved my understanding of the legal system from first principles, at least as it exists in Spain and other Spanish-speaking countries.

If you're looking for an L5 class, this is a good option. It will help you practice and improve your written Spanish, and some of the material covered is very interesting. If you're looking to be challenged and really improve your spoken Spanish, this might not be the course for you.

I would recommend this course to another student because I improved my Spanish speaking, writing, listening, and reading abilities. I also learned about a topic I did not know much about previously. I left the course feeling well-informed and excited to continue improving my Spanish.
Yes! The professor is very understanding and the reading material (although sometimes difficult to understand immediately) is extremely interesting.
